Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Applying the AGO Network to Energy Transfer in the Radiation Belts and Remote Sensing of Auroral Plasma Processes
Award.AbstractNarration: With this award, researchers at Dartmouth College and Stanford University will be addressing outstanding scientific questions regarding the energy transfer in the Earth's radiation belts and auroral plasma physics. Energetic plasma interacting with the geomagnetic field in the near-Earth space (geospace) environment emits electromagnetic waves across the radio spectrum, and ground-based measurements of these waves are used as diagnostic tools to investigate various processes in geospace. This investigation takes advantage of an existing network of radio receivers located in Antarctica from -70 to -85 degrees of invariant geomagnetic latitude and operating in the frequency range from extra low to high frequencies (ELF ~300 Hz to HF ~5 MHz). The Antarctic continent is ideally suited for these types of natural radio wave experiments since it is largely devoid of anthropogenic electromagnetic interference such as power line harmonics and radio frequency broadcast transmissions. The project will focus on studies of three geophysically important plasma waves. The first, chorus wave is believed to be a major driver of radiation belt electron acceleration and loss. The other two waves, auroral hiss and auroral kilometric radiation (AKR), are generated in the auroral acceleration region and have the potential to be used for remote sensing of this complex and poorly understood near-Earth region. The proposed studies are motivated by a recent, exciting detection of AKR on the Earth?s surface which was unexpected since the currently accepted theory for these waves generation predicts beaming of the radiation only outward away from Earth. This research also contributes to the training and education of both the young scientists and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this award, Stanford University operated an extremely and very low frequency (ELF/VLF) radio receiver at South Pole Station, Antarctica that measures and records electromagnetic waves in 300Hz-40 kHz frequency range. The magnetic component of the electromagnetic waves are received via two orthogonal, 18 meter base, triangular cross-loop wire antennas, and the two channels of data are sampled at 100 kilosamples per second with approximately 96 dB of dynamic range. The system is capable of measuring signals on the order of a femtotesla. The primary purpose of the receiver is to record waves that are naturally generated in the Earth’s high altitude plasma environment, a region known as the magnetosphere.

The Earth’s magnetosphere is a dynamic configuration of magnetized plasmas that are driven and energized by the flow of solar wind past the Earth. The geospace environment spontaneously emits electromagnetic waves across the radio frequency spectrum. The waves are generated by the conversion of free energy within the plasma into wave energy through a variety of plasma-wave processes. Once generated, the waves may propagate for some distance and impart their energy on an entirely different plasma population. Thus, these emissions play an extremely important role in the transfer of energy in geospace. Also, due to their ability to transmit information over long distances and to penetrate through the ionosphere to the ground, the waves can also be used to remotely sense a variety of space plasma processes. The scientific investigations under this award focused on two types of electromagnetic electron plasma waves generated in geospace, referred to as chorus and auroral hiss.

Chorus is a whistler-mode plasma wave generated by the electron cyclotron instability in the near equatorial region on closed field lines.  Long data records from the ELF/VLF receiver at South Pole were used to statistically examine the response of magnetospheric chorus emissions to different types of geomagnetic storms and the relationship to changes in the outer belt electron population. Chorus waves have a high occurrence in the outer dayside magnetosphere. However, during the main phase of geomagnetic storms, there is a significant dropout in the wave occurrence at South Pole. We conclude that magnetospheric chorus population observed at South Pole is not driven by storm-time activity, and chorus in the outer dayside magnetosphere likely does not play a role in the recovery of outer belt.

Auroral Hiss is generated in the auroral region at altitudes from below 1000 to above 10,000 km and can extend in frequency from 1–1500 kHz. Auroral hiss generation is tied to the complex physics of the auroral acceleration region, and as such, many features of the waves are poorly understood, including the wide range of fine-scale and periodic spectral structure. We performed a statistical analysis of auroral hiss observations from South Pole station to examine the variation of auroral hiss as a function of season, magnetic local time, geomagnetic conditions, and interplanetary magnetic field conditions. This unprecedentedly large database of observations allows us to examine hiss observations in the context of global magnetospheric configuration. We find that auroral hiss generation is closely linked to the auroral boundary locations and the upward field-aligned current regions, and changes in the global configuration of the auroral boundaries and the upward field-aligned current regions due to changing solar wind driving results in changes in auroral hiss as observed at South Pole. We also investigate fine scale frequency-time structure in auroral hiss, which can be used in remote sensing of density characteristics at altitudes of thousands of kilometers.
